If it applies to the server, do not skip step 11. If you do so, the system will overwrite the existing rings with new rings. This will not cause data loss, but potentially will move most objects in your system to new locations and may make data unavailable until the replication process has completed.The procedure to the replace a Swift node in a system is a follows:
Log onto the deployer.
Update the cloud model (data/servers.yml file) with a new MAC address, iLO/IPMI user, password, and IP address (iLO) if these have changed. There is no need to change the actual IP address. For example: - id: swpac2 role: SWPAC-ROLE server-group: rack2 mac-addr: 8c:dc:d4:b5:cb:bd nic-mapping: HP-DL360-6PORT ip-addr: 10.243.131.10 ilo-ip: 10.1.12.88 ilo-user: iLOuser ilo-password: iLOpass ...
Commit the changes to git.cd ~helion git commit -a -m "<commit message>"
Run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the following command to create a deployment directory.cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Remove the replaced Swift node from cobbler by executing the following command:sudo cobbler system remove --name <server-id>
For example:sudo cobbler system remove --name swpac2
Re-run the cobbler deploy playbook to re-add the replaced node:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml
Using ansible, reimage the node:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<server id>
In the example below swobj2 server is reimaged.cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=swpac2
Examine the cloudConfig.yml and data/control_plane.yml files to get the host prefix (for example, helion) and the control plane name (for example, ccp). This gives you the hostname of the node. Configure the operating system as follows.cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml –limit <hostname>
In the following example, for swobj2, the hostname is helion-ccp-swpac2. cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml –limit helion-ccp-swpac2*
If this is the first server running the swift-proxy service (see identifying first proxy server) you need to restore the Swift Ring Builder files to the /etc/swiftlm/builder_dir directory. See recovering builder files for details.
Configuring services on the node using the site.yml playbook. If you have used an encryption password when running the Configuration processor include the --ask-vault-pass argument.ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml --ask-vault-pass --limit <hostname>
For example:ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml --ask-vault-pass --limit helion-ccp-swpac2*
